customer_name: East Coast Zoological Society of Florida

citations.narrative:
On two separate occasions, a bird was injured by a guest in the walk-through aviaries. On February 08, 2024, a rainbow
lorikeet was stepped on by a guest resulting in its death. On November 16, 2024, a cockatiel was stepped on by a guest
resulting in its death.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of the
animals and the public.
The facility must ensure that the birds cannot be injured or killed in the walk-through aviary.
Correct from this date forward June 30, 2025

At the exhibit housing 5 white-tailed deer, 1 axis deer, 4 turkey and 1 sandhill crane, there are 3 public feed dispensers
(gumball style) spread around a U-shaped exhibit. This exhibit measured approximately 105 paces (roughly 210ft). Due to
the vegetation within the exhibit, it was not possible to see the entirety of the public interaction space from any one point.
At the time of inspection, there was 1 volunteer in the area but when USDA inspectors were at the location of 2 food
dispensers the attendant could not be seen.
Without an attendant present to monitor interactions, both animals and members of the public are at greater risk of injury.
A responsible, knowledgeable and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods
of public interaction.
Correct by July 14, 2025

The licensee did not ensure that animals housed in the same pen didn’t cause them pain or discomfort.
On September 15, 2024, keepers noted that the male bongo, Sebastian (20079) was seen approaching the male zebra,
Bakari (20075) “along the fence line of holding. He was seen putting his horn through the fence when Bakari would
approach and Bakari was seen trying to bite him through the fence.” It was also noted that this behavior is “becoming
more frequent.”
On September 20, 2024 while they were both in the train yard, Bakari was found standing at the train yard gate bleeding
from a wound under his left front leg. At the same time, keepers found Sebastian had blood on his horn.
At euthanasia on September 25, 2024, it was noted that Bakari had 3 broken ribs and damage to organs inside his chest.
Animals may suffer from stress, injury, or death when housed near or in the same enclosure with other animals with which
they are or become incompatible.
The facility must ensure that animals housed in the same enclosure are compatible, and that animals are not housed near
other animals that interfere with their health or that cause them discomfort.
The licensee corrected this issue before the inspection, which was on June 26, 2025.

The licensee did not ensure that animals housed in the same pen were compatible and were not hazardous to the health
and well-being of each other.
On January 29, 2024, a domestic chicken was attacked by a bloodhound (facilities collection) in the petting zoo. The
chicken died during the vet examination.
Animals may suffer from stress, injury, or death when housed with other animals with which they are or become
incompatible.
The facility must ensure that animals housed in the same enclosure are compatible, and that animals are not housed near
other animals that interfere with their health or that cause them discomfort.
The licensee corrected this issue before the inspection, which was on June 26, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Moira Roberts, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On two separate occasions, a bird was injured by a guest in the walk-through aviaries. On February 08, 2024, a rainbow 
lorikeet was stepped on by a guest resulting in its death. On November 16, 2024, a cockatiel was stepped on by a guest 
resulting in its death.  
 
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with 
sufficient distance and or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of the 
animals and the public.  
 
The facility must ensure that the birds cannot be injured or killed in the walk-through aviary.  
 
Correct from this date forward June 30, 2025 
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
At the exhibit housing 5 white-tailed deer, 1 axis deer, 4 turkey and 1 sandhill crane, there are 3 public feed dispensers 
(gumball style) spread around a U-shaped exhibit. This exhibit measured approximately 105 paces (roughly 210ft). Due to 
the vegetation within the exhibit, it was not possible to see the entirety of the public interaction space from any one point. 
At the time of inspection, there was 1 volunteer in the area but when USDA inspectors were at the location of 2 food 
dispensers the attendant could not be seen.  
 
Without an attendant present to monitor interactions, both animals and members of the public are at greater risk of injury. 
 
A responsible, knowledgeable and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods 
of public interaction.  
 
Correct by July 14, 2025

3.133  Critical
   
Separation. 
The licensee did not ensure that animals housed in the same pen didn’t cause them pain or discomfort.  
 
On September 15, 2024, keepers noted that the male bongo, Sebastian (20079) was seen approaching the male zebra, 
Bakari (20075) “along the fence line of holding. He was seen putting his horn through the fence when Bakari would 
approach and Bakari was seen trying to bite him through the fence.” It was also noted that this behavior is “becoming 
more frequent.” 
 
On September 20, 2024 while they were both in the train yard, Bakari was found standing at the train yard gate bleeding 
from a wound under his left front leg. At the same time, keepers found Sebastian had blood on his horn.  
 
At euthanasia on September 25, 2024, it was noted that Bakari had 3 broken ribs and damage to organs inside his chest. 
 
Animals may suffer from stress, injury, or death when housed near or in the same enclosure with other animals with which 
they are or become incompatible. 
 
The facility must ensure that animals housed in the same enclosure are compatible, and that animals are not housed near 
other animals that interfere with their health or that cause them discomfort. 
 
The licensee corrected this issue before the inspection, which was on June 26, 2025. 
3.160(b)  Critical
   
Compatibility and separation 
The licensee did not ensure that animals housed in the same pen were compatible and were not hazardous to the health 
and well-being of each other.  
 
On January 29, 2024, a domestic chicken was attacked by a bloodhound (facilities collection) in the petting zoo. The 
chicken died during the vet examination. 
 
Animals may suffer from stress, injury, or death when housed with other animals with which they are or become 
incompatible. 
 
 
The facility must ensure that animals housed in the same enclosure are compatible, and that animals are not housed near 
other animals that interfere with their health or that cause them discomfort. 
 
The licensee corrected this issue before the inspection, which was on June 26, 2025

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Moira Roberts, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
